text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 5.12.4, Judicial and Non-Judicial Foreclosures.
CHANGES (

) Editorial changes made throughout. Updated terminology and references; revised wording for clariﬁcation and compliance with writing standards; restructured subsections to improve ﬂow and comprehension; and corrected formatting issues. Signiﬁcant additions or deletions to the text noted as follows. (

Added Note that the Centralized Lien Operation may process DOJ requests instead of Advisory. Deleted generic information about the economy’s impact on foreclosures. Moved information about power of sale clauses to
Inserted paragraphs regarding the power of sale clause and the delegations of relative to non-judicial sales. (
Added paragraph about personal delivery services and note about the use of Form (
Inserted cross-reference to perishable goods seizures. (
Updated to incorporate language from Interim Guidance Memo SBSE-
Added note about the use of Form
Updated to incorporate language from Interim Guidance Memo SBSE-

) Exhibit
Deleted exhibit because letter is now a published document.

Editorial changes made throughout. Updated terminology and references; revised wording for clariﬁcation and compliance with writing standards; restructured subsections to improve ﬂow and comprehension; and corrected formatting issues. Signiﬁcant additions or deletions to the text are
5.12.4.3.1 Inserted paragraphs regarding the power of sale clause and the delegations of authority relative to non-judicial sales.
5.12.4.4. Added paragraph about personal delivery services and note about the use of Form 14497.
Exhibit 5.12.4-1. Deleted exhibit because letter is now a published document.
ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This material supersedes IRM 5.12.4 dated June 11, 2010, and Interim Guidance Memo SBSE-05-0714- 0040, titled Change to Deﬁnition of Designated Payment Code 07, dated July 22, 2014.
Small Business/ Self-Employed Collection Employees
Table of Contents
Foreclosures

) A foreclosure is the process by which an owner’s right to a property is nated, the foreclosing party’s interest is liquidated, and junior creditor on the property are extinguished. This IRM contains instructions and tion related to third party foreclosures. It does not address suits initiated by IRS to foreclose its lien interests. (See IRM
, Suits by the United (
) There are two types of foreclosures discussed in this IRM. • Judicial foreclosures, as referenced in
USC §
and
USC §
(a) • Non-judicial foreclosures, as referenced in
USC §

) State law determines the type of foreclosure a creditor must use to enforce interest-- judicial or non-judicial. The location of the property being determines which state’s laws are followed. See the Local Law Guides for formation about each state’s laws. (

) Judicial foreclosures are processed either in federal or state courts and are primary responsibility of the Department of Justice (DOJ). When DOJ assistance or information, the request is generally handled through Advisory (“Advisory”). Note: This IRM is written as if Advisory handles the cases, but the procedures apply to any function involved in the foreclosure process. For example, in certain jurisdictions DOJ requests for lien information are handled by the Centralized Lien Operation (CLO). (
) Non-judicial foreclosures do not require court involvement and can be insti- gated by any encumbrance holder. Non-judicial foreclosure notices are generally directed to Advisory. (

) When Advisory requires assistance investigating a foreclosure, a courtesy/ other investigation (OI) is issued to the Field. Revenue Officers may also during routine case investigation that property belonging to an assigned taxpayer is in foreclosure. (

) There are four classes of participants to keep in mind when working foreclo- sures. • Foreclosing party (i.e., the lender or lienholder) • Foreclosed party (i.e., the borrower) • Creditors (e.g., IRS, secondary mortgages, judgment holders) • Foreclosure sale purchaser (

) Each participant has differing responsibilities or needs during the process. When working foreclosures, the IRS employee may need to apprise the pating parties of the applicable federal statutes pertaining to their part of the foreclosure process. • The foreclosing party must provide notice to all interested parties of the closure suit commencement (judicial) or sale (non-judicial). • The foreclosed party may have tax consequences arising from the A portion of their debt may be forgiven which translates to taxable See Mortgage Debt Relief Act of
and IRM
, Mortgage giveness. • Creditors such as the IRS must determine whether they were properly noticed, how the foreclosure impacts their interest in the property, Internal Revenue Manual
Judicial/Non-Judicial Foreclosures

) A foreclosure is the process by which an owner’s right to a property is termi- nated, the foreclosing party’s interest is liquidated, and junior creditor interests on the property are extinguished. This IRM contains instructions and informa- tion related to third party foreclosures. It does not address suits initiated by the IRS to foreclose its lien interests. (See IRM
, Suits by the United States) (
) There are two types of foreclosures discussed in this IRM. • Judicial foreclosures, as referenced in
USC §
and
USC §
(a) • Non-judicial foreclosures, as referenced in
USC §

) State law determines the type of foreclosure a creditor must use to enforce its interest-- judicial or non-judicial. The location of the property being foreclosed determines which state’s laws are followed. See the Local Law Guides for in- formation about each state’s laws. (

) Judicial foreclosures are processed either in federal or state courts and are the primary responsibility of the Department of Justice (DOJ). When DOJ requires assistance or information, the request is generally handled through Collection Advisory (“Advisory”). Note: This IRM is written as if Advisory handles the cases, but the procedures apply to any function involved in the foreclosure process. For example, in certain jurisdictions DOJ requests for lien information are handled by the

• The foreclosing party must provide notice to all interested parties of the closure suit commencement (judicial) or sale (non-judicial). • The foreclosed party may have tax consequences arising from the process. A portion of their debt may be forgiven which translates to taxable income. See Mortgage Debt Relief Act of
and IRM
, Mortgage For- giveness. • Creditors such as the IRS must determine whether they were properly noticed, how the foreclosure impacts their interest in the property, whether
Creditors such as the IRS must determine whether they were properly noticed, how the foreclosure impacts their interest in the property, whether

Federal Tax there are surplus or excess proceeds in which they may have an and whether redemption from the foreclosure sale purchaser is a ation. • The foreclosure sale purchaser should be aware of the government’s re- demption rights. (
) See IRM
, Suits Against the United States, for additional information about foreclosures. See IRM Exhibit
, Glossary of Common in IRM
, for common acronyms used in this section. (

) The purpose of a judicial or non-judicial investigation is to determine ﬁrst whether the foreclosing party holds an encumbrance senior or junior to the IRS’ position. • If the foreclosing encumbrance is junior to the IRS’ position, the federal lien remains on the property undisturbed by the foreclosure. The IRS be asked by the purchaser to discharge the property from the lien. • If the foreclosing encumbrance is senior to the IRS’ position, the federal lien will be extinguished from the property after the foreclosure sale, as provided by state law. An investigation may be needed to determine how equity in the property is impacted by the foreclosure and whether any is warranted to protect that interest. (
) Other Investigations (OI) to investigate foreclosures originate in Advisory. (

) During the course of a judicial or non-judicial investigation, when the taxpayer, representative, or IRS employee misses a speciﬁc deadline, follow-up is based on meeting the Service’s requirements to maintain its standing in the proceeding and should be initiated no later than fourteen calendar days after the missed deadline. This follow-up includes closing the case if this action is appropriate. (

) When circumstances dictate, the employee should use problem solving and negotiation techniques, and in so doing consider the perspective of the taxpayer/POA/third party when working toward case resolution. (
) Any written notiﬁcation or other communication should address the issue(s) clearly and in a language understandable to someone unfamiliar with IRS terms, acronyms, and jargon. (
) A foreclosing lienholder should be encouraged to request a discharge of property from the lien under IRC

) before initiating the foreclosure action rather than join the United States in a judicial proceeding. It would their advantage to eliminate the Government’s right of redemption and to government’s advantage to eliminate lengthy litigation. (

) When a discharge is requested before the foreclosure, review the request following standard discharge guidelines and take the following actions. a. Furnish a commitment letter to the foreclosing party within thirty (

) calendar days of receipt of a complete and acceptable application. b. Issue the certiﬁcate of discharge after receipt of proof that the taxpayer has been divested of right, title, or interest in the property. Caution: Do not issue a certiﬁcate of discharge during the pendency of without the prior approval of Area Counsel. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

there are surplus or excess proceeds in which they may have an interest, and whether redemption from the foreclosure sale purchaser is a
Other Investigations (OI) to investigate foreclosures originate in Advisory.
When a discharge is requested before the foreclosure, review the request following standard discharge guidelines and take the following actions.
Caution: Do not issue a certiﬁcate of discharge during the pendency of litigation without the prior approval of Area Counsel.
Foreclosures
page (
) In non-judicial foreclosures, a discharge commitment letter should not be issued if adequate notice of sale has been provided as required by IRC
(see IRM
, Adequacy of IRC
Notice). If a discharge is requested, advise the parties of the procedures for requesting the release of the government’s right of redemption, as described in Pub
, How to Prepare an Application to Release of Property Secured by Federal Tax Lien. (

) If a Federal agency has foreclosed non-judicially and given adequate notice, but thinks the lien remains a cloud upon the title, a certiﬁcate of discharge should be issued as an accommodation to that agency. (

) The subject of mortgage forgiveness may be encountered when working closure cases. The information provided here is for an awareness of a taxpayer’s potential tax consequence arising from foreclosure. (

) When lenders foreclose and sell a borrower’s property or restructure the bor- rower’s loan, the lender may forgive or cancel portions of the loan. A lender may use this as an alternative to, or in conjunction with, a deﬁciency against the borrower for the balance remaining on the loan after the foreclo- sure sale. The tax code treats the amount forgiven as income to be taxed. following are typical scenarios where loan forgiveness may be encountered. • Lender modiﬁes loan reducing the principal balance of loan and the borrower keeps house • Property is sold and deeded back to the lender • Lender forecloses and the property sells for less than the amount of the loan (

) Cancellation of debt may impact the IRS’ decision to discharge or a lien interest related to a foreclosure investigation. Asking the lender or borrower whether a portion of the debt will be cancelled should be added to the foreclosure investigation questions for those parties. (

) The amount forgiven is all or a portion of the remaining amount on the loan minus the new loan or minus the sale amount of the property. This forgiven amount becomes cancellation of debt income (COD) to the COD income must be included as ordinary income on the taxpayer’s return unless exclusion is allowable. (
) The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of

increased incentives for borrowers and lenders to work together when the foreclosure involves the rower’s principal residence. The law lessens the income tax burden created debt forgiveness, resulting from mortgage restructuring or foreclosure, by allowing taxpayers to secure lower mortgage payments without facing higher taxes or at least not having a higher tax bill because of a foreclosure. See documents below for additional information on this topic:: • IRS FAQs – Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act found at gov/uac/Home-Foreclosure-and-Debt-Cancellation • Form
, Reduction of Tax Attributes Due to Discharge of Indebtedness (And Section

of the United States Code is the authority under the United States consents to be sued in suits to quiet title, foreclose a mortgage or other lien, partition, condemn, or interplead a claim, or suits nature of an interpleader with respect to property on which the United has, or claims, a mortgage or other lien. (

) When the foreclosure action is by an encumbrance holder that is junior to federal tax lien, the sale of the property shall be made without disturbing federal tax lien. However, if the United States agrees that the property be free and clear of its liens, the proceeds from the sale are distributed to the priorities of the interests of the various parties involved. (

) When the foreclosure action, to which the United States has been made party, is by an encumbrance holder that has priority over the federal tax the sale extinguishes the federal tax lien on that particular property. The has the same effect on the Government’s lien as it would on any other lien under local law in the place where the property is situated. (
) See IRM
, Judicial Foreclosures, for additional information. (
) The Department of Justice (DOJ) through the U.S. Attorney’s office is sible for working
USC Section
foreclosures. DOJ requests from Advisory as needed when working these cases but case priority is dependent on DOJ resources. (

) Assistance required by DOJ of the IRS may include the following: • Determination of the IRS lien priority • Determination regarding surplus or excess proceeds • Redemption investigation • Other information as requested (

) When the IRS is joined in a foreclosure action, the Assistant U.S. office (AUSA) forwards a copy of the summons and complaint, along with request for the information needed to prepare an answer, to the Advisory office. (

) Promptly screen the request against the Notice of Federal Tax Lien ﬁles and determine the balance due on the liens involved in the Provide information to the AUSA so they can take the legal action propriate. a. If there is no outstanding liability, advise the AUSA so that a can be ﬁled on behalf of the United States. b. If there is an outstanding liability for NFTLs involved in the furnish any information requested by the AUSA that may be obtained without a formal investigation (e.g., payoff information). Note: Payoff information may be provided through a standard IRS letter such Letter
-C, Lien Payoff for Judicial Foreclosure, or another format to by the local AUSA. (
) In all cases where the government has a lien interest, take the following actions

When the foreclosure action, to which the United States has been made a party, is by an encumbrance holder that has priority over the federal tax lien, the sale extinguishes the federal tax lien on that particular property. The sale has the same effect on the Government’s lien as it would on any other junior lien under local law in the place where the property is situated.
(06-03-2016) Judicial Foreclosure Case Responsibility

If there is no outstanding liability, advise the AUSA so that a disclaimer can be ﬁled on behalf of the United States. If there is an outstanding liability for NFTLs involved in the proceedings, furnish any information requested by the AUSA that may be obtained without a formal investigation (e.g., payoff information).
In all cases where the government has a lien interest, take the following
Judicial/Non-Judicial Foreclosures 5.12.4
Foreclosures
a. Open a Non-Field Other Investigation (NFOI)
, Judicial ICS no later than seven (
) calendar days after receipt. b. Document the receipt date of the notice of judicial foreclosure. c. Establish a case ﬁle. (
) If a redemption investigation is needed, follow up with the AUSA or the for the date of sale. (

) When the property is sold for an amount greater than the balances due on foreclosing instrument plus other liens senior to the federal tax lien, take to obtain the surplus (or excess) proceeds for application to the taxpayer’s account. (

) Each area is responsible for establishing the time frame and methodology following up on foreclosure case issues. However, during the course of an vestigation, when the applicant, taxpayer, representative, or IRS employee misses a speciﬁc deadline, follow-up is based on meeting the Service’s re- quirements to maintain its standing in the proceeding and should be no later than fourteen (
) calendar days after the missed deadline. This follow-up includes closing the case, if appropriate. Established procedures should strive to provide a minimum of ninety (
) calendar days remaining available to conduct a redemption investigation. (
) When a revenue officer is assigned to investigate a foreclosure, the RO provide the following to Advisory by the date speciﬁed on the Courtesy gation: • A completed Form
, Report of Investigation (IRC
or
or a memorandum detailing the situation • The original history documentation, if not on ICS • Any other information requested by the U.S. Attorney (
) The United States has the right to redeem property sold at foreclosure and resell it. This redemption process and redemption investigations are more Redeem covered in IRM
, Redemptions. Sold at Judicial (
USC
(c) provides that where a sale of real estate is made to lien prior to that of the United States, the United States shall have

calendar days from the date of sale (or the period allowed by state law, if longer) to redeem the property. This gives time to investigate and whether it would be to the advantage of the United States to redeem the property. (

) Redemption provides the IRS an opportunity to resell the foreclosed for more than the cost of redemption with the resulting beneﬁt to the ment. A principal consideration in such an investigation entails a as to whether the value of the property sold in the foreclosure proceeding reasonably in excess of the amount required to effect the redemption. (
) When a courtesy investigation is necessary to determine whether to the right of redemption, it is generally issued by Advisory within thirty (
) calendar days before or after the scheduled date of sale, thus allowing the maximum amount of time to complete the redemption process. (
) In cases where it appears that redemption may be feasible, the assigned employee retains the Courtesy Investigation and the original Form
A (

copy of the Form 4376 and any other information requested by the Attorney is returned to the Advisory GM by the due date of the OI.
Note: The responsibilities and actions shown in the chart are general statements and may vary based on case facts and availability of resources.
The positions authorized to determine the adequacy of notice and consent to the sale is addressed in IRM 1.2.44.5, Delegation Order 5-4 (Rev. 3).

• in writing, • by registered or certiﬁed mail or by personal service, • to the Advisory group manager (or other delegated office) for the Field lection Area where the sale is to be held, and • not less than twenty-ﬁve (
) calendar days prior to the sale.
Exception: Notice for a sale of perishable goods does not have the 25-day re- quirement. See IRM 5.12.4.5, Non-Judicial Sale of Perishable
) For purposes of IRC

, “personal service” may be accomplished by the of personal delivery services (PDS) such as Federal Express and United Parcel Service. For PDS, the date of service is the date of actual delivery, not the date the notice given to the delivery service. For USPS registered or certiﬁed mail, the date of service is the mailing date. (
) Persons seeking information on when or how to submit a notice of sale should be directed to IRS.gov for, or furnished a copy of, the following documents: • Pub
, Instructions for Preparing Notice of Non-judicial Sale of Property and Application for Consent to Sale • Pub
, Collection Advisory Group Addresses Note: Pub
includes Form

, Notice of Nonjudicial Sale of Property, may be used to provide notice of the sale.. The use of this form is not a re- quirement. The form is available to facilitate a consistent format for foreclosing creditors, especially when they are not familiar with the informa- tion required for effective noticing. The form has ﬁelds for optional information that would be beneﬁcial to processing, but completion of those ﬁelds is not mandatory. The creditors are only required to provide the infor- mation mandated by IRC
) In situations where a NFTL has not been ﬁled or has been ﬁled less than thirty-one (

) calendar days before the sale, it is not necessary for the fore- closing party to notify the Advisory group manager of the sale. In these situations, the sale shall discharge the property from the federal tax lien just it does under local law for other junior liens. (

) When the sale is postponed, the seller of the property is required to give of the postponement to the Advisory group manager in the same manner required under local law with respect to other secured creditors. If the postponed sale date is more than
calendar days from the NFTL ﬁling date, notice of sale is required to be given even though such notice was not origi- nally required. (
) In the case of a forfeiture of a land sales contract, Area Counsel should be consulted to determine if the IRS has a redemption right.
In the case of a forfeiture of a land sales contract, Area Counsel should be consulted to determine if the IRS has a redemption right.
The date of the sale is determined by how the junior liens will be divested from their interest in the property. Determine the date of sale by following the chart

their interest in the property. Determine the date of sale by following the the Date of below. Sale If divestment results... The date of sale is deemed to be the date when... Directly from a public sale The public sale is held, regardless of the date under local law on which junior liens on the property are divested or the title to the property is transferred Directly from a private sale The property is transferred, regard- less of the date junior liens on the property are divested under local law Not directly from a public or Junior liens on the property are private sale divested under local law

Review the notice of sale for timeliness and adequacy. If the notice was not submitted timely, the federal tax lien will not be by the pending sale, unless the United States consents to the sale free tax lien.. The foreclosing lienholder will be required to either: • pay the amount of the tax lien in full, or • request a discharge of the property from the tax lien. No formal investigation is required when the items to be sold are goods. Provide a copy of the notice of sale to the employee assigned balance due to decide what further action is required, if any. in the history. Review the notice for adequacy. It is considered adequate if it contains following information: • Name and address of the person submitting the notice of sale • Copy of each Form

• Name and address of the person submitting the notice of sale • Copy of each Form

, Notice of Inadequacy of Nonjudicial Sale Notice. Reminder: Any written notiﬁcation or other communication should address the issue(s) clearly and in a language understandable to someone iar with IRS terms, acronyms, and jargon. (
) The Advisory group manager may, at their discretion, consent to the sale property free of the lien or title of the United States even though notice of sale is not given twenty-ﬁve (
) calendar days prior to the sale or is inadequate. (
) In any case where the person who submitted a timely notice does not written notiﬁcation that the notice is inadequate more than ﬁve (
) days prior to the date of the sale, the notice will be considered adequate. (

) The Advisory executive will provide an alternative method for the internal tracking of receipts and dispositions where the acknowledgement of the or inadequacy of the notice is the only issue such that the case is not onto ICS. (

) A written request for the acknowledgment of the receipt of a notice of sale should be honored as resources allow. Acknowledgement can be made of through the mailing of a duplicate notice or via facsimile as long as the party is agreeable to the method. (

) Any person desiring this information should submit a written request to the Advisory group manager that states their name and address, clearly the property sold, identiﬁes the applicable NFTL(s), and gives the reasons requesting the information. (

The term “perishable goods” means any tangible personal property which, in the reasonable view of the person selling the property, is liable to perish or become greatly reduced in price or value by keeping, or cannot be kept without great expense.
become greatly reduced in price or value by keeping, or cannot be kept without great expense. Note: This deﬁnition is the same used by the IRS in its authorization to sell pursuant to IRC
(see IRM
, Perishable Goods Criteria, tions, and Examples). (
) Notice of the sale must be given: • in writing • by registered or certiﬁed mail or by personal service • to the Advisory group manager before such sale. (
) The notice of sale of perishable goods shall contain the same information required in IRM
, Notice of Non-Judicial Sale. (
) In the event of a postponement of the scheduled sale of perishable goods, seller is not required to notify the Advisory group manager of the ment. (
) If notice requirements are met, the sale will discharge the subject property from the lien or title of the United States. The proceeds are not (

) For provisions relating to the authority of the Advisory group manager to discharge property where the proceeds of the sale are held as a fund to the liens and claims of the United States, refer to IRM
, tion of Proceeds of Sale. (
) The proceeds of the sale (exclusive of costs) are held as a fund for not than thirty (

) calendar days after the date of the sale and remain subject the liens and claims of the United States. Distribution of the fund is in the same manner and with the same priority as the liens and claims had with respect to the property sold. (
) If the seller fails to hold the proceeds of the sale in a fund in accordance the provisions of IRC
), the seller becomes personally liable to United States for an amount equal to the value of the interest of the States in the fund. (

) The buyer of the perishable property is afforded certain protection. Even if proceeds of the sale are not held by the seller but all the other provisions satisﬁed, the buyer of the property at the sale takes the property free of liens and claims of the United States. (
) A consent to sale by the United States under IRC

Reminder: See IRM 1.2.44.5, Delegation Order 5-4 (rev. 3), for positions autho- rized to give consent.
Foreclosures
page (

) Consent to the sale may be given when adequate protection is afforded the lien or title of the United States. Protection is considered adequate if any of following are present. • Taxpayer has no equity in the property • Proceeds of sale are substituted as provided in IRC

) • Taxpayer’s interest in the property is assigned to the United States • Assignment of proceeds in excess of prior encumbrances is secured • Other circumstances that make consent acceptable to the IRS (
) The consent: • is effective only if given in writing, • is subject to such limitations and conditions as may be required by the and • may not be given after the date of the sale. (
) The right to redeem remains even though a consent to the sale is given. (
) The consent to a sale under IRC
must be approved by the Advisory group manager or other delegated authority. (
) Apply all payments directly related to consents to sale to the taxpayer’s account using Designated Payment Code (DPC)
) Any person requesting consent to sell property free of the lien (or title from the enforcement of the lien) must submit an original and two copies of Consent information required in Pub
. Note: Pub
includes Form

, Application for Consent to Sale of Free of the Federal Tax Lien, which may be used to request consent. The use of this form is not a requirement. The form is available to facilitate a consistent format for foreclosing creditors, especially when they are not familiar with the information required. The form has ﬁelds for optional mation that would be beneﬁcial to processing, but completion of those is not mandatory. (
) The information required, as stated in Pub

, can be submitted from an external source (e.g., foreclosure attorney) as long as the electronic transmission includes all of the required information and is submitted under penalties of perjury declaration.. An electronic signature is acceptable. Inter- nally, the information can be forwarded via secured messaging. (

) As a general rule, consent may be given without a ﬁeld investigation if the property is: • of nominal value, • consumer goods, or • real property in which the Government’s interest is less than the criteria tablished in IRM
, Criteria for Working Redemption (

) If the property is real property in which the Government’s interest is more the redemption investigation criteria, the application for consent should be vestigated to determine the most feasible administrative action to take. See IRM
, Criteria for Working Redemption Investigations. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

) Consent to the sale may be given when adequate protection is afforded lien or title of the United States. Protection is considered adequate if any following are present. • Taxpayer has no equity in the property • Proceeds of sale are substituted as provided in IRC

) • Taxpayer’s interest in the property is assigned to the United States • Assignment of proceeds in excess of prior encumbrances is secured • Other circumstances that make consent acceptable to the IRS (
) The consent: • is effective only if given in writing, • is subject to such limitations and conditions as may be required by the and • may not be given after the date of the sale. (
) The right to redeem remains even though a consent to the sale is given. (
) The consent to a sale under IRC
must be approved by the Advisory group manager or other delegated authority. (
) Apply all payments directly related to consents to sale to the taxpayer’s account using Designated Payment Code (DPC)
) Any person requesting consent to sell property free of the lien (or title from the enforcement of the lien) must submit an original and two copies information required in Pub

, Application for Consent to Sale of Free of the Federal Tax Lien, which may be used to request consent. The use of this form is not a requirement. The form is available to facilitate a consistent format for foreclosing creditors, especially when they are not familiar with the information required. The form has ﬁelds for optional mation that would be beneﬁcial to processing, but completion of those is not mandatory. (
) The information required, as stated in Pub

, can be submitted from an external source (e.g., foreclosure attorney) as long as the electronic transmission includes all of the required information and is submitted under penalties of perjury declaration.. An electronic signature is acceptable. Inter- nally, the information can be forwarded via secured messaging. (

) As a general rule, consent may be given without a ﬁeld investigation if the property is: • of nominal value, • consumer goods, or • real property in which the Government’s interest is less than the criteria tablished in IRM
, Criteria for Working Redemption (

) When consent to a non-judicial foreclosure sale is given, prepare the letter which includes the following information. • Name and address of person requesting consent • Reference to the authority under IRC

) • Detailed description of property to be discharged • Description of liens to be divested. • Unpaid balance of the federal tax liens, including accruals • Date and place NFTL(s) ﬁled. • Statement that surplus proceeds are subject to the liens of the United States. • Signature of approving official (normally Advisory Group Manager) (
) Provide the original and a copy of the consent letter to the requestor. copy of the letter for the case ﬁle. (
) When it is determined that consent to the sale should not be given, letter that informs of the non-consent and contains the following • Name and address of requestor • Reference to IRC
) • Recommended alternate procedure (e.g., discharge of property, of proceeds of sale, etc.) • Signature of the approving official (normally Advisory Group Manager) (

) Certain situations may warrant investigation by a ﬁeld revenue officer. Generally, Ols to investigate non-judicial sales originate in Advisory. The decision to issue an OI is contingent upon factors such as the following. • Geographic feasibility • Dollar amount of the liability • Type of property involved • Economic condition of the particular locality • Practical impact of local law • Any other signiﬁcant factor (

) Due to the need for immediate assignment of these cases, route the OI to the ﬁeld revenue officer group working the zip code. The Field Group Manager must treat the OI as priority work. The OI must be assigned to a revenue officer expeditiously to ensure that the government’s interest is not compromised and that the investigation is completed accurately and timely. Non-judicial foreclosure OIs are exempt from existing case delivery param- eters. (
) The only time Advisory needs to review notices of sale is when the notice meets the criteria in (
) above. (

) For a notice of sale where an investigation is needed, determine the tion period applicable under local law, which then determines the time for a revenue officer to conduct the investigation. Consult Area Counsel, as needed, regarding redemption period questions. (

) If the foreclosure relates to a case assigned to the ﬁeld, provide a copy of Notice of Sale to the assigned revenue officer to decide what further action should be taken. If the case is not assigned, has been reported currently collectible, or is assigned to ACS, note the history accordingly. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
G

(06-03-2016) Non-Judicial Sale Activities and Tasks
Foreclosures
page (
) Issue the outgoing OI via ICS no earlier than thirty (

) calendar days prior to the scheduled date of sale. Before issuing the OI, determine if the fair market value of the property in question exceeds the amount required to redeem. Sources from which this information can be secured varies, but examples include the tax assessor’s office and the foreclosing creditor’s attorney. (

) The revenue officer need not attend the sale, unless speciﬁcally directed by Advisory. Attendance should be requested only in unusual cases. The necessary information may generally be secured from the seller or seller’s agent immediately after the sale. (
) Each Advisory territory is responsible for establishing the time frame and odology for following up. Established procedures should strive to provide a minimum of ninety (
) calendar days remaining available to conduct a re- demption investigation. See IRM
, Investigation Guidelines for Judicial/Non-Judicial Sales, for other investigation guidelines. (
) The revenue officer or Advisory (if no ﬁeld involvement) prepares Form
, Report of Investigation (IRC
and
USC), to provide a recommenda- tion whether to exercise the right of redemption. (

) The primary purpose of the non-judicial foreclosure sale investigation is to determine how much the property sells for in relation to the amount owed on the foreclosing party’s encumbrance and the fair market value of the property. A signiﬁcant difference in either or both may result in action by the IRS. • If the sale produces an amount in excess of the foreclosing party’s prior encumbrance (plus other required costs), a determination is needed regarding the surplus (or excess) proceeds. • Regardless of the presence of surplus proceeds, if the property sells for than its fair market value, a determination is needed whether sufficient equity remains for the IRS to exercise its redemption rights. (

) In the event of surplus proceeds, the employee assigned determines what party handles these funds. It could either be the one that conducted the sale another party charged with that responsibility by state law. (
) There are two methods the IRS has to pursue surplus proceeds-- issuing a levy or ﬁling a claim. (
) Issue Form
-A(c), Notice of Levy, when a Letter
, Final Notice Reply Within

Days, has been issued for all applicable tax periods and the IRS reason to believe that the holder of the surplus proceeds is not disbursing funds in accordance with the legal requirements or is disbursing them to a creditor junior to the IRS. • The levy may only include those modules where all Collection Due (CDP) appeal rights are extinguished or resolved. If the CDP process has been completed on some but not all modules, issue the levy containing those modules. • If the proceeds available will more than full pay the levy and there are remaining liabilities, or if the liabilities have not been through the CDP process, do not issue a levy. File a claim as described in (
) If the IRS cannot levy for the excess sale proceeds, the statutory lien and the IRS must look to its rights as a creditor under the laws of the state in (
) Internal Revenue Manual

• The levy may only include those modules where all Collection Due Process (CDP) appeal rights are extinguished or resolved. If the CDP process has been completed on some but not all modules, issue the levy containing only those modules. • If the proceeds available will more than full pay the levy and there are remaining liabilities, or if the liabilities have not been through the appropriate CDP process, do not issue a levy. File a claim as described in (
If the IRS cannot levy for the excess sale proceeds, the statutory lien remains and the IRS must look to its rights as a creditor under the laws of the state in

which the foreclosure and sale took place. Use Form 10492, Notice of Federal Taxes Due, to serve as written notice to the settlement attorney or other third party that the IRS may be entitled to excess proceeds. State law controls how and to whom a claim for the proceeds is submitted.

Taxes Due, to serve as written notice to the settlement attorney or other party that the IRS may be entitled to excess proceeds. State law controls and to whom a claim for the proceeds is submitted. • Some, but not all, states require the party distributing the proceeds to use the priority order of the junior liens attached to the property prior to the closure sale. Sometimes an interpleader suit is initiated by the party responsible to distribute the funds to determine who has rights to the Address questions to Area Counsel. (
) The employee’s investigation should determine if there is a problem with distribution of the funds and, if appropriate, recommend involvement of Area Counsel. (
) Apply all payments directly related to non-judicial sales to the taxpayer’s account using Designated Payment Code (DPC)
) IRC

(d) provides for the redemption by the Government of real property sold in a non-judicial proceeding when such sale is made to satisfy a lien is prior to the United States. The period for redemption is
calendar days the period provided by State law, whichever is longer. (
) If the sale is of real property either the advisor or the revenue officer, based assignment of the investigation, completes Form

with their tion regarding the right of redemption. ) Procedures for redemption investigations are found in IRM
, Redemp- tions. That IRM covers the investigation leading up to the decision to the redemption itself, and the sale of the redeemed property. (

) Upset bidding after a foreclosure sale is allowed in some states like North Carolina. An upset bid is a recorded bid placed after a foreclosure sale has ended. It is higher than the highest bid received at the actual foreclosure This type of bidding can cause confusion when conducting a redemption tigation because it impacts the person from whom the IRS would redeem property. (

) An upset bid extends the bidding period but does not change the sale date which IRS uses to start the redemption period. Consult Advisory and when encountering upset bidding and considering redeeming property. (

) The upset price, also called the judgment amount or minimum bid, is what lender is owed on the property. This sum usually includes the outstanding and any interest and fees accumulated since the start of the foreclosure process. It is a bid made after a judicial sale but before the successful bid at the sale has been conﬁrmed, larger or better than such successful bid, and Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
G

Some, but not all, states require the party distributing the proceeds to use the priority order of the junior liens attached to the property prior to the closure sale. Sometimes an interpleader suit is initiated by the party responsible to distribute the funds to determine who has rights to the Address questions to Area Counsel.

) Upset bidding after a foreclosure sale is allowed in some states like North Carolina. An upset bid is a recorded bid placed after a foreclosure sale has ended. It is higher than the highest bid received at the actual foreclosure sale. This type of bidding can cause confusion when conducting a redemption inves- tigation because it impacts the person from whom the IRS would redeem the property. (

) An upset bid extends the bidding period but does not change the sale date which IRS uses to start the redemption period. Consult Advisory and Counsel when encountering upset bidding and considering redeeming property. (

) The upset price, also called the judgment amount or minimum bid, is what the lender is owed on the property. This sum usually includes the outstanding loan and any interest and fees accumulated since the start of the foreclosure process. It is a bid made after a judicial sale but before the successful bid at the sale has been conﬁrmed, larger or better than such successful bid, and
made for the purpose of upsetting the sale. It provides the ″upset bidder″ the privilege of taking the property at this bid or competing at a new sale.
